awd_titl_txt: Interaction of Type Ia Supernovae with their Environment and Implications for Cosmology
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Hoeflich and his collaborators will conduct a theoretical study of supernova explosions of the Ia type.  These have been attributed to white dwarf stars which accrete material from a binary companion.  This project will study the initial phases of the explosion and the interaction of the rapidly expanding material with the accretion disk.  The principal goal will be to identify signatures of the interaction that can be observed spectroscopically.  The researchers also anticipate that computational techniques developed under this project can be used for other types of supernovae and for the study of stellar mergers.

Type Ia supernovae have been used to determine the distance scale to distant galaxies, which has revealed the presence of a significant 'dark energy' component to the universe.  The research activities under this award will contribute to workforce development and student training, and will help build the astrophysics program at Florida State University, which was established in 2006.  This program has ongoing outreach activities with nearby middle school students.

Stellar explosion play a central role in modern Astronomy and Cosmology. After millions to billion of years, some stars end their lives with a powerful explosion within seconds. What we observe as supernovae (SNe) is the light emitted from a rapidly expanding envelope for months to years.  SNe are observed both locally and at so large distances that it take the light to travel 10,000,000,000 years allowing to observed the present and past Universe. A subclass, Type Ia SNe Ia, can be used as cosmic light beacons to measure the universe because a tight relation between brightness and the decline rate of the light emitted, the curves (LC). This led to the discovery that our Universe isexpanding at an accelerated rate driven by a 'dark energy' compromising some 70% of all energy in the Universe. However, to probe for its nature, we need to probe the history of the expansion with high precision and a better understanding of the diversity of SNe Ia.
 We know that SNe Ia are thermonuclear explosions at final stages of stellar evolution of low mass stars, so called white dwarfs (WDs). If thea WD is member of a close stellar system,  an explosion can be triggered by accretion from the wide variety of companion star or the merging of two WDs. SNeIa are so similar because basic nuclear physics determines the WD structure, the explosion, and the LC leading to 'stellar amnesia' of their past. This strength allows us to use SNeIa and 'standard candles' to measure the Universe but also causes problems when probing the explosion and diversity of the progenitor system and is in the way of higher precision.

In our project, we studied the imprint of the progenitor system on the observed light curves and spectra.
 Why do we not see an ongoing interaction between the supernova with the interstellar matter as can be expected from typical densities in the surrounding ? What are the observational signatures and tell tails ?

We used a three-prong approach to study the observable signatures: 1) Semi-analytical solutions allow us evaluate a wide range of potential environments. 2) Advanced hydrodynamical simulations are used to study components to be expected such as accretion disks.  3) Observations are used to verify progenitor scenarios, or limit the parameter space realized in nature.

We found that the lack of ongoing interaction can be understood: Typical wind from the accretion disk in the progenitor system produce a cocoon of 1 to 50 light years diameter with underdensities of 100 to 10000 compared the the  general interstellar matter. The supernovae envelope expands with velocities between 10,000 and 60,000 km/sec freely for several years to decades. X-rays and radio has not been observed for SN Ia but, now, we have quantified the sensitivity of X- and radio observations needed to probe the environment. We expect strong interaction with the shell starting some 2-3 years to 50 years after the explosion lasting a few weeks to months.  We started an observational program for historical, nearby supernovae such as SN1972e and SN1984a. We suspected that a commonly seen velocity Ca II feature  in the spectra may be attributed to interaction with an accretion disk but detailed simulations excluded this solution (or interaction with the companion star). More likely, the SN material may interact with a common envelope bound in the progenitor system and overrun within minutes. The project did highly benefit from the advances in observations. For SN2014J, lack of X-rays and radio were suggestive that the progenitor system constitutes of two merging WDs whereas narrow lines of NaI have been seen as an indication for the explosion of a WD with an accretion disk. By covering the entire parameter space, we found as a solution which is consistent with all observations.
